The truth is that the one giving the advice is a vilderavn, who seeks to bring ruin to Adannos's tribe, just as he did in the past with the first tribe he tempted.
A large number of displaced goblinoids gathered by the hobgoblin Razghora settled at Razghora's Camp in Druma.

Records Hall, located in the aristocratic district of The Greens, once stored all records of Kintargo's nobility. However, in the decades since House Thrune's ascension, the once impeccable records have been altered, redacted, and ravaged, and the collection is a shadow of its former self.

Red Kestrel Imports had existed in Magnimar since 4702 AR. Its red warehouse in the northern portion Ordellia district flies the flags of the six nations it operates out of—Absalom, Cheliax, Osirion, Katapesh, Sargava, and, of course, Magnimar.

As of 4712 AR, it was run by Anton Ghanafini.

Red Mountain is the tallest point of Smuggler's Shiv, an island that is technically part of Vidrian and located off its western shores. The entire island can been seen from the mountain's peak, and its slopes compose most of the island's southeastern quadrant. The mountain is named for its red stones, a mundane side effect of a nearby temple of Zura.

Red Rune Canyon, located in the eastern Tusk Mountains of the Realm of the Mammoth Lords, is an interconnected maze of canyons tainted by the relentless expansion of the Worldwound. Festering black boils and sores weep red bloodlike mud from its walls. The canyons change form under the demonic influence, with blasphemous runes etched into Golarion's surface. The evil of Red Rune Canyon drives any living creature who enters it mad.

Larisa, a cambion sorcerer, arrived to Red Rune Canyon in 4713 AR. Using blasphemous sacrifices at each new moon, she gained control of the glyphs inscribed by the canyon. Each sacrifice calls forth a new symbol and siphons power from the distant Worldwound. When she bends the canyon into her grand final rune, she will get rid of her mortal blood and metamorphose into a full demon.

The reshaping of the Red Rune Canyon has weakened the barriers between Golarion and the Outer Rifts. At each of Larisa's rituals, a new gate is forced open for a few seconds, oozing demons out into the Tusk Mountains.

Redroof Market satisfies the mercantile needs of the lower-class Redroof district of Kintargo. While Redroof Market contains all the essentials—butchers, greengrocers, etc.—it is most renowned for its array of clothing merchants who sell everything from Chelaxian wares to more exotic foreign styles. It is also renowned for offering a range of leather goods and for its cobblers.
Reiver's Right is a former logging camp that has been long abandoned. The former loggers here became victims of a forest blight and were transformed into trees, and the blight still remains here.

The haunted fortress-monastery of Renchurch in the damned Ustalavic province of Virlych is one of the headquarters of the undead-obsessed Whispering Way. It is overseen by the Gray Friar, a powerful huecuva cleric of Urgathoa.

Once a fertile village in central Thuvia, Resa is now little more than a flat stretch of desert with a few scattered signs of civilization.

During the decline of Osirion's first age, an Usij necromancer named Aryana Tahari took sanctuary beneath the village and used its inhabitants as test subjects in experiments to create a new plague. These experiments eventually lead to the downfall of the village and its citizens.

The Katharevousa River meets the Yolubilis River in the Revousa Ditches, deep rents in the ground that are prone to flooding. The site is so well traveled by riverboats that temporary shops set up on anchored, floating platforms at all times except during the rainy season. The Ditches are believed to be home to a rusalka.
Rhuvasi was a dwarven settlement whose inhabitants were forced out by the dwarves of Taggoret after the Battle of Scattered Ash.

An old rickety bridge spans the Thorn River about a dozen miles south of the Thorn River bandit camp. The river is about 20-foot-deep here, passing between two rugged hills. Local bandits are aware that the creaking bridge will surely collapse if they do not cross it one by one.

The Riddleport Light is built on a lonely crag at the edge of Riddleport's eastern ridge, south of the Rotgut District. The lighthouse provides guidance to the safety of Riddleport Harbor and away from the treacherous rocks just to the east of the harbor's mouth. It is reached by a narrow winding stairway and is the home of a sorcerer named Gebediah Krix.

The Rift of Niltak is a mist-shrouded canyon found in the Red Mountains of north-eastern Varisia. No one knows what the origins of the rift are, but all agree that it is filled with all manner of strange flora and fauna. Gigantic insects and centipede horrors can be seen crawling over plants found in no other place on Golarion, and the echoes of shrieking bat-like creatures reverberate off the glen's walls.

An accurate description of the rift has not come to light, as those who enter either never return, go insane, or kill themselves shortly after emerging from it.

Rimakak is a former Erutaki settlement on the coast of Lake Nallishoot in the Gaarjuk Hills in the Crown of the World. This village was cursed by a qallupilluk named Arnaalak, and the villagers, unable to fight back, fled the village.

Rimeskull is a mountain on the western edge of the Kodar Mountains in northwestern Varisia. Located on the banks of Lake Stormunder, it is named for the vaguely skull-shaped carving visible from miles away, the mouth of which is a large cave entrance.

The carving is a relic of ancient Thassilon, and the person depicted in the massive carving is the founder of Thassilon itself: Emperor Xin. During the time of this ancient empire, runelords commonly carved their faces into the mountainsides that faced their capital cities. The carving of Xin, however, faces the Runeforge, a place of great importance shared by all of the runelords.

At the mountain's western base, just off the lake, lies a ring of seven ten-foot-tall, open-mouthed stone heads angled toward each other known as the Sihedron Circle. This Thassilonian ruin was recently discovered to be a magical entrance to the Runeforge.

The territorial white dragon Arkrhyst makes his home on Rimeskull and endangers any expedition there.

Rivenstone is a submerged mountain within the Broken Bay region of the Lands of the Linnorm Kings that causes great trouble to passing ships. Rivenstone rises up from the depth of one of the deepest valleys of the Steaming Sea, splitting on its way up into seven separate peaks. The highest two peaks reach just below the sea's surface except at the lowest tides when they poke above the tideline; they are known to local sailors but seem to have a knack for sinking visiting ships. Another danger is the presence of a Dagon-worshipping tribe of intelligent gutaki devilfish. They are led by a cabal of a dozen priests, a mix of clerics and oracles, who use charmed giant octopuses and squid to bolster their tribe making them one of the deadliest threats to dwell within Broken Bay.

Located in the Loric Fells, Rookwarden is a stone and granite fortress built by dwarves in 4636 AR. Situated on the bluff of a quarry rich with marble, this fortress is easily defended by even a small number of soldiers. According to rumor, a secret network of tunnels honeycombs beneath the fortress and allegedly leads to entrances that could be used to take the fortress without an extended siege.

The history of the fortress is closely tied with the history of Loric Fells, with a rich history of occupation, from dwarves to humans to goblins and trolls.

The Rose and Rake Theater, sometimes spelt the Rose and Rake Theatre, is the beating heart of the Ordellia district of the Varisian city of Magnimar. Ordellia has always regarded itself as somewhat of a separate political entity from the rest of the city being separated from them by the Yondabakari River. The Rose and Rake Theater, an open-air theatre that is renowned for its scathing political satires and controversial critiques of Magnimar's government, serves as the heart of this political entity.
Roslar's Coffer was a small town located in southwestern Lastwall along the Tourondel River, near the border with the Hold of Belkzen.

Rovagug's Hall is a ruin that is most known for being raided by a group that took their name after their exploits here, the Raiders of Rovagug's Hall, and is located in the southwest section of the Scrape region of the Isle of Kortos.

Ruba's Shop is a scrivener's shop in the Old Kintargo district of Kintargo that also serves as a notary and translator. Unbeknownst to most, the owner—the elderly Varisian, Ruba Fenquay—is also an accomplished forger whose other illegal sideline business is copying forbidden texts.

The Rune Mausoleum is one of the cyclopean monuments of ancient Thassilon, built with the labor of enslaved rune and stone giants. It was located in the southwestern part of the Thassilonian nation of Cyrusian, now western Varisia near the Mierani Forest.

The Rust Gate straddles the border between Kintargo's districts of Old Kintargo and Redroof and is the city's most heavily trafficked gate. Most of the traffic crossing through it comes from the Ravounel Road, the busiest roadway in the city, which leads to Kintargo from the south and over the Argo Bridge.

Ryvanthnyl is a memorial located in the eastern part of Kyonin. The site is dedicated to the lives and traditions of people and cultures that perished and are remembered by the elves who preserve their memory by leaving behind works of art and objects of significance.

Ryvanthnyl is protected by gravekeepers and preserved through magic that safeguards the objects within, though the origin, era, and historical significance of many of these objects remain unknown.

Sabertooth Vale is a valley within the Wolfcrags in the far northwest of the Sarkoris region of Frostmire. Prior to the Worldwound's closure in 4718 AR, it achieved some notoriety as the home of the evil and destructive Roaring Sabertooth tribe of Kellid barbarians.

Sabkha is a shallow basin filled with gritty salt-laden sand. It is the primary source for the nagri salt that farmers use to make pesh. Farmers travel to Sabkha once a season to sift salt out of the dirt and carry sacks of it home. Merchants flock to Sabkha to collect nagri salt, which they then sell in the markets of Katapesh. Once a month or so, heavy rains fill Sabkha's shallow basin with trapped rainwater. After several days, the water drains out through the rock, leaving new salt deposits on the surface.

Sable Barrow is a hill that overlooks the Numerian city of Chesed. The Pathfinder Gojan the Sharp observed a golden statue appear on the Barrow the night before a seemingly inevitable slave revolt. The statue hefted a mighty hammer and seemed to be threatening the city with it, and carried the mark of the god Abadar on his chest armor. Gojan believed that the statue's presence prevented the slave revolt, and it disappeared four days later. Most agree that the golden statue was actually the Lawgiver, the herald of Abadar.

Lawgiver's appearance instead inspired the slaves to join with the city's defenders in order to repel an unprecedented, and since unequaled, assault upon the city by barbarians. After the city's successful defense against the raid, Chesed abolished its slave trade, emancipated its slaves, and decreed that any slave brought into the city would be declared free within an hour of arrival if not registered with the city's government.

The Sable Sands are a desolate location in the southeastern deserts of Katapesh that is avoided by most travellers; the only people who visit are the occasional lost travellers who mistake it for a distant oasis.

The Sable Sands are about 100 feet in diameter and filled with a tarry, black substance that covers the ground in strange patterns. From the midst of the tar protrude several weather-worn tombstones, though no one knows who or what may have been buried beneath the sable sands.

The tar that permeates the ground seems to suck the happiness and positivity out of all who come near it, leeching the warmth from the very air itself. Though no undead have ever crawled from the tar-filled graves, the area does seem to attract them, drawing all sorts of living dead toward this desolate site.

Saddlebark Ranch is a breeder and trainer of faerie mounts and Taldan corgis located in the foothills of the Kortos Mounts on the Isle of Kortos. Its proprietor is Timblethorn Baublebrand, who launched the ranch after recognizing that riding dogs were more surefooted than axebeaks or camels in the Mounts.

Once an innovator, Saddlebark was as of 4720 AR merely one of a dozen such ranches in the region, and the Aspis Consortium had been bullying ranchers and acquiring property for a cut of the business.

The Saffron House is a crumbling mansion once owned by Cleid Thord located within the murky Sclerain Swamp in eastern Canterwall, one of the counties of Ustalav. There is something very wrong about this haunted and abandoned home: it is claustrophobic inside, the sheet-covered furniture is mouldy and there are noises from within the walls. Many of its room seem stunted or underformed, while others seem cripplingly small. Even stranger is a repulsive yellowing on every surface. Not many know of this house and fewer understand its blighted nature.

Saintsgrove is a small area of ancient olive trees in the south-east of the county of Sinaria, in Ustalav, lying near the southern banks of Lake Prophyria, and to the south-east of Karcau.

Legends speak of a priestess of Urgathoa who performed a sacrilegious ceremony to transform herself into a Daughter of Urgathoa at this spot, perverting a shrine of Desna and sacrificing the followers of the Song of the Spheres as part of her ritual. Such blasphemy apparently stirred Desna to direct action against the priestess by immediately ageing the olive trees by a thousand years, trapping the blasphemer and preventing her ritual from succeeding, while providing a grave for her dead worshippers.
The Sallix Salt Works are the largest and oldest such business in all Kintargo and are located in the oldest part of the city, Old Kintargo.
The Salmon is one of the ten remaining pilings of the Irespan in Magnimar. It stands 220 feet high. There are no known entrances into the piling.

Once the busiest gate in the city, the Salt Gate is now a useless relic. The internal workings of the gate have rusted so much that the gate can no longer be used and is stuck open. The Salt Gate's usage declined as a growing amount of shipping moved from nearby Old Harbor to Yolubilis Harbor and the Foreign Quarter of Jarvis End, but it is still used by the traders of Salt Market.

The Salt Market, despite its misleading name, mainly deals in building supplies and it is the first port of call for Kintargo's architects and builders. Its location in Old Kintargo just inside the Salt Gate gives it easy access to the Yolubilis River from which much of its goods are delivered.
Sampadabad is a ruined city in the north-west of Vudra's storied central region known as the Cradle. Sampadabad was not a Vudrani city but rather one built by nagas.

The Sanctum of Sand is a mysterious location in the desert of southern Katapesh. It is believed to be located inside a valley within the Trackless Storm and is the origin of the Decanter of Black Breath artifact.
Sanctum of the Sorrowmaker is a labyrinthine cavern complex in Dahak's Fang island that Aashaq the Annihilator and her minions call home.

Sanctum's Watch was built to guard a pass in the Southern Range of the World's Edge Mountains in the Taldan province of Ligos, a purpose which it no longer serves. Sanctum's Watch is a fortress expertly hidden amongst the mountains and the valley itself was a sight of much bloodshed in the early days of the Grand Campaign, when the Taldan army faced off against the forces of Qadira. Seen as an easy way to march an army into the soft belly of Taldor, the valley was eventually fortified, which discouraged Qadira from ever trying this approach again and led to disuse. After several centuries Sanctum's Watch was all but abandoned, with Taldan officials even forgetting how the hidden fortress was accessed.

Sangoshi was a metropolis on an island off the southeastern cost of Minkai before being overtaken by the Okaiyo Ocean hundreds of years ago. Its ruins are now a coral reef miles off the eastern shore of modern Minkai. Tales suggest the ruins rise from the depths for one day every 44 years.

The cave-pocked Saresp Mountain, a peak in Mendev's far eastern reaches, was once the site of many ancient tombs as well as shelters for families seeking refuge from the harshest parts of winter. The caves hosted many Sarkorian refugees after the opening of the Worldwound, but all disappeared near the end of the Mendevian Crusades, their caves either sealed or apparently struck by grave robbers.
Sarini Estate, located in the Greens district of Kintargo, Ravounel, is the home of House Sarini. Most of its Thrune-loyalist residents fled Kintargo after the Kintargan Rebellion.

The Satyr Shoals are a group of islands in the southern part of Iblydos formed by sand and shells being carried up from the Obari Ocean. The unstable nature of the islands means permanent settlements are frequently buried or resurfaced as the topology of the islands change. Because of this, none of the nearby city-states want the land, and anyone found here are likely pirates or other types who want to stay away from the eyes of any authorities.

The ruined city of Saventh-Yhi (pronounced saa-vinth-YHEE) is located in the southern Mwangi Jungle, east of the Ocota River, just north of the Bandu Hills. The city was founded more than 10,000 years ago during the Age of Legend by followers of the Azlanti hero Savith, who died while defeating the serpentfolk god Ydersius in the Darklands' tunnels below.

Scar Thicket is a forbidding overgrown area deep in the namesake Scarhusrt region of the Whisperwood of Cheliax, tucked between the flows of the Doracium, Malvesa, and Iseld rivers.

Infrequently visited because of its evil reputation, this area remains a primal woodland and frequently features in hushed conversations and outlandish stories. Everything from monstrous [[insect]s, deformed animals, and enormous bats are rumored to emerge from its depths. Youths in the area grow up learning to deal with evil outsiders, and the inhabitants are quite skilled at leading hunts for them.

The Scar of the Spider is a small, fungi-encrusted vale in the southwestern Felldales of Numeria, just north of the West Sellen River. Generally avoided by everyone, this valley of gray stone spears is said to be the home of a steel arachnid that strikes terror into even the stoutest warriors. Other legends tell of a glass coffin located somewhere in the vale, wherein writhes a dancing and whistling enigma.
Scarnetti Villa is a the residence of House Scarnetti, one of Magnimar's newest noble families.
The immense gothic fortress of Scarwall is located in the far-eastern reaches of the Kodar Mountains within the Hold of Belkzen.
Schloss Caromarc is an abandoned castle in the northeast of the Ustalavic county of Vieland, and is the former residence of Vieland's ex-ruler, Count Alpon Caromarc.

Scrag Deep is an extensive underwater system of caverns at the deepest point of the Glacier Lake in Irrisen.

In the Winter War a tribe of scrags under the command of the great warlord Tirchagac, fought the longships of the Djurstor Confederacy on Glacier Lake. As a reward, Baba Yaga gave the scrags dominion over the Scrag Deep. Scrag Deep is still home of the Scrag Deep tribe descendants of the allies of Baba Yaga.

Scrapwall is a town in the Sellen Hills built out of a gigantic technological junkyard almost 3 miles in length. Having never had a formal leader in its thousands of years of history, the city is instead run by disparate rival gangs.

Sea King Shipyards is a small shipyard in the Docks district of the city of Absalom. The yard builds only one ocean-going vessel at a time, but it remains famous for the high quality and sturdiness of its fluyts and galleons that can sail the most dangerous waters in the Inner Sea.

The Sea Wrack Chapel is a small temple dedicated to Gozreh that serves the pirate city of Port Peril.

Like many seaside settlements, Port Peril has a small shrine dedicated to Gozreh for pious sailors to make offerings to the Lord of Waves. No larger or more impressive than the shrine of a typical fishing village, Sea Wrack Chapel is made from driftwood and discarded fishing nets but is still large enough to provide shelter to those seeking Gozreh's guidance.

Sea Wrack Chapel is tended to by Father Ignalus, a halfling priest who accepts Gozreh worshippers of any creed, including in the form of Shimye-Magalla, a dualistic deity worshipped in the Mwangi Expanse. Father Ignalus is also a meticulous record keeper and has kept track of every single shipwreck that has occurred in the vicinity of Port Peril.

Sech Nevali is a relic from the Thassilonian realm of Haruka. Also called the Hanging Monastery, it is a vast stone temple complex built upon a very thick metal platform suspended over a mile-deep chasm by three immense chains attached to three nearby mountain peaks. A fourth chain failed centuries ago, making the monastery sway disconcertingly in strong winds.

The Seerspring Garden is the largest park in Magnimar and forms a tranquil corner of the Keystone district but borders other city districts too. The Seerspring Garden is named after the Seerspring, a beautiful spring that produces pure, crystal-clear water. The spring is said to have been home to a water spirit that acted as an oracle early in the city's history, while this water spirit has long since disappeared it predicted that it would one day return to the Seerspring. This prophecy and the springs generally mysterious nature led the aiuvarin wizard Leis Nivlandis to found the wizard school called the Stone of the Seers directly opposite the Seerspring Garden.

At the center of the spring stands Our Lady of Blessed Waters, a statue that may depict the water spirit. The sculptor is unknown; the statue just appeared in the spring one day shortly after the park's opening.

The red granite city of Sele in the Mwangi Expanse was once the site of an ancient Mauxi culture. The city's foundations were built on limestone, and eventually it sank beneath the waters of the Mbernbe River. This may have been a catalyst for the Mauxi migration into Thuvia. The only structure which remains above water—a domed palace—is home to a family of wyverns.

An enormous headless stone torso known as Selkelas is half-buried near the western edge of the Katapesh desert. Its size indicates that, had it been a fully detailed humanoid statue, it would have measured at least 20 feet in height. The name "Selkelas" is engraved on the statue's back. One of its granite hands seems to have been carved to hold a now-missing weapon, perhaps a sword.
Sepet Pass is a high pass in the Brazen Peaks in Osirion on the route between Ipeq and El-Fatar. At the top of the pass, the Hostel Sepet provides safety for travelers.

Seraph's Ladder is a freestanding golden and white marble ladder that stands on the Blood Plains of the Hold of Belkzen. It is believed that Seraph's Ladder is one of the few remnants of the Thassilonian domain of Gastash, dating from the reign of Zutha, Runelord of Gluttony.
Serenity's Copse is a community of dryads who live in a grove deep in Cheliax's Anferita Wood.

Serpent's Run is the largest building in Magnimar, quite a feat in the so-called city of monuments, and is located in one of the city's most prosperous areas, the Marble District. Serpent's Run is Magnimar's arena and most popular entertainment venue; the hippodrome can seat up to 5,000 people, over a quarter of Magnimar's total population. Unlike many other arenas, the Serpent's Run specialises in non-bloodsports like dog and horse racing, decathlons, and magic displays. However, the late-summer rodeos sponsored by the Matador's Lodge are also held here.

The arena is named for the carving of a gigantic serpent that runs around the upper rim of the arena, a tribute to the serpent slain by Alcaydian Indros. It is run by Master of Games Jorston "Axetongue" Droaeb.

The Seven Stelae is a collection of massive pillars located between Shiman-Sekh and the port city of Totra in Osirion. The red granite pillars bear the symbols of Pharaoh An-Hepsu I. Several doors and chambers in the pillars have been found.

Seven's Sawmill is the oldest of the six major sawmills on Kyver's Islet in Magnimar and has never changed ownership. Production occurs here, but not in significant volumes, because it is used as the meeting place of the secret society called the Brothers of the Seven. Few know of the group or the meetings.

The Seven-Fangs Bastion is the ruined remains of an orc fort dating back to the Age of Darkness. It was built under the supervision of the vrock known as Seven-Fangs. It is located in the Mindspin Mountains; as of 4717 AR it was inside the borders of Nirmathas, but as of 4719 AR it was within the borders of the new hobgoblin nation of Oprak.

The Severed Spiral is a circle of 43 standing stones surrounding seven dolmens located deep within the Estrovian Forest of Mendev. The western half of the circle's stones are made of dark, rough-hewn basalt and other dark-colored stones, while the eastern stones are made of white, smooth dolomite.

The circle is the only permanent holy site of the Children of Balance, an organization of religious two-headed trolls led by Romrix who worship deities that most closely embody the duality and dichotomy of their lives—especially Pharasma, Nethys, and Gozreh.
The Shadefields are a battleground marked by a simple stone cairn that commemorates one of the fiercest battles ever fought between the orcs and the Shoanti of Varisia's Storval Plateau.

The Shadow Caverns are located in Nidal's sinister Uskwood, not far from the capital Pangolais. On the surface they appear to be nothing more than a cave above an icy spring, but they conceal an entrance to the Darklands.

The Shadow Clock is a 250-foot-tall clocktower in Magnimar's Underbridge district. It is a rusting and leaning structure of stone, wood, and metal. Like the rest of Underbridge it is in constant shadow from the Irespan. An angelic statue is positioned atop the tower, and the clock is frozen at 3 o'clock.

At least 10 people have died trying to climb the inside stairs, which earned them the nickname "Terrible Stairs". While ordered closed by the city, this tower still stands.

Local rumors say ghosts or other nasty inhabitants reside in the tower. However, as of 4712 AR it was the lair of the Scarecrow, a flesh golem made over 100 years ago by the Brothers of the Seven.

Despite its appearance as a rural paradise, locals have shunned the ivy-covered hunting lodge named Shadowreach in Nidal's southern Uskwood for years. The area is infested with lethal shadow creatures, and rumors circulate about even more perilous dangers lurking among the nearby trees.
Shadowsquare is the second-largest temple in Kintargo, Ravounel. Devoted to Zon-Kuthon, it is located in the north-eastern part of the Temple Hill district.

The ruins of the Qadiran town of Shadun are located in the eastern foothills of the Zho Mountains, on the opposite side of the mountain range from Gurat. The hillsides around the town were once covered in terrace farms watered by the tributaries of the Pashman River, and criss-crossed with green trails. Tragedy struck when the nearby volcanoes Zhonar and Zhobl began spewing great clouds of dust and ash that covered the countryside, forcing the town's inhabitants to flee. No one is quite sure what happened to the citizens of Shadun, and today its desolate streets are stalked at night by strange shadowy figures with eyes like glowing embers.

The Shaping Bluffs are a two-mile-long geologic feature along the Sellen River and the border it forms with Galt, and is known for the mysterious tendency of its bluffs to constantly reshape their faces. The steep cliffs expose red stone that changes erratically regardless of any winds or waters and can hide or reveal caves at water level.

The cliffs house a camp of dwarven stone shamans and geomancers, led by Hromcul Stetruk, who have stabilized their location enough to continue studying the phenomenon. The Shaping Bluffs are also used by river pirates who take advantage of the transient nature of caves that appear and disappear along the water level to raid traffic along the Sellen River.
The Shark is one of the ten remaining pilings of the Irespan in Magnimar. Standing 120 feet high, this piling is rumored to be haunted. There is an entrance in the upper piling.
The Sharpened Axe of Urgir in the Hold of Belkzen is a fighting school located on the southeastern side of the city's fourth level.

The Shay Citadels is a gnome monastery established on the island of Irrere, in the Ironbound Archipelago of the Steaming Sea, soon after their exile from the First World. It is located at the base of a waterfall next to the town of Irrere.

The Citadels consist of a number of towers with twisted spires of multi-coloured glass that rise above the waterfall's mists. The monastery was established for research and meditation, and is a regular destination for gnome pilgrims, especially those suffering from the Bleaching.

The monastery sometimes temporarily phases out of existence. Upon returning, all of its buildings remain intact but no gnomes except for the Bleachlings return with it.

The cliff-top citadel of Shepherd's Rock is situated in the Napsune Mountains in Rahadoum and has a commanding view of the nearby desert. As of 4711 AR, it was the centre of operations for the Pure Legion and residence of the organisation's leader Karsakim, the Sword of Man.

The citadel's Vault of Lies houses the Legion's vast store of confiscated religious writings. It also trains new recruits into the Pure Legion.

The ruins of the city of Shevaroth, once one of Kyonin's most populous pre-Earthfall cities, are located on the plains southeast of the Fierani Forest. Abandoned by the elves fleeing Earthfall to Castrovel, Shevaroth fell under the dominion of the nascent demon lord Treerazer in 2633 AR, and as of 4725 AR it had not been retaken.

The Shipmakers' Guild is one of the most powerful unions in Magnimar. They are based in the Beacon's Point district. It is owned by House Scarnetti, but Magnimar's navy has a somewhat permanent loan of a third of the shipyards, which is an increasingly irritating situation for the Scarnettis.

Sholay is a huge pool of magma in the lower southern foothills of the Lohaparbat Mountains in the Falling Mountains region of the Impossible Kingdoms of Vudra. The mechanical god Dhuangir is said to lie buried beneath this stretch of mountains, and Sholay is the result of his hryngar followers' attempt to excavate parts of Dhuangir from beneath the range.

Shotep-Kara on the Scorpion Coast of Osirion was a military and commercial hub connecting Tumen to the Obari Ocean. The port city lost its prominent role after the death of the Four Pharaohs and the ruin of Tumen. A number of earthquakes and tsunamis finally drew the city into the sea in 1687 AR.

Shotep-Kara's ancient monuments and temples are now part of the underwater ruins, and the place remains imbued with powerful magic. At the height of Four Pharaohs' reign, conjuration magic connected the port to the far corners of the empire and beyond. The magic is believed to persist to this day, though in wildly unstable form. Oceanic horrors and unquiet spirits infest the waters, but Shotep-Kara might still offer magical passage to faraway places, or even to other planes.

The Shouk is a tribe of degenerate ogrekin that once were human holy men. Their lair is in the Barrier Wall mountains, roughly south-east of the Thuvian city of Duwwor. Once the Shouk were holy men and oracles of some renown. Their wisdom was sought by many other nomadic tribes. However, at some point in the distant past, this clan of holy men became tainted by the blood of ogres and ogrekin began to be born among the ranks of the Shouk. With each generation the taint spread, and more and more brutish, vile ogrekin were born. Now the tribe is composed exclusively of ogrekin, and has lost all prophetic ability. Purely out of tradition, the tribes of the area still occasionally seek out the Shouk in times of great need. These visits rarely yield any result other than the loss of life, as the Shouk are also now cannibals.

The Shrike Cascade is a waterfall on the Shrike River situated about a dozen miles downriver from the Crooked Falls. Here, the Shrike drops from a slippery 50-foot-high cliff, which offers an excellent view of the surrounding landscape, but makes any travel by boat impossible.

The Shrine of Saint Senex is not dedicated to a deity but instead to the centuries-dead Senex, an oracle who devoted her life to recovering the drowned dead of Nisroch Bay and the Yolubilis River. The shrine is now all but forgotten by the modern world; Saint Senex fell in popularity after the Chelaxian Civil War, lying unremembered on a stretch of swampy coast on Argo Isle, just south of the city of Kintargo. The driftwood shrine is devoted to drowned sailors, including a buried sanctum that is home to the bodies of dozens of unknown drowned. The shrine is shielded from magical divination and has sometimes been used as a secret safe house by Hellknights of the Order of the Torrent. Thanks to its decline in prominence, the shrine's only inhabitants are now a pair of rag-clad oracles.

An abandoned shrine to the goddess Sarenrae exists in the Underbridge district of the Varisian city of Magnimar. It was built in the early days of the settlement by a priest of the goddess named Father Vosten, who felt that the burgeoning community could use the Dawnflower's guidance.

He was approached a few months after its completion by Sczarni thugs who demanded protection money. When he refused to pay and attempted to drive them off, he and his acolytes were killed. Their bodies were buried in the small graveyard behind the shrine.

The shrine has lain abandoned ever since, as no devotee of Sarenrae has come forward to rebuild it.
The Shucked Oyster is a brothel in the Dockway district of Magnimar. Seeshaw Raccas is its madam.

Sicnavier's Lair is a dark chasm located in the Hungry Mountains in eastern Virlych, a grim mountain range in southern Ustalav.

A place haunted by the spirits of evil dragons, Sicnavier's Lair is always ruled by a sole umbral dragon who had succeeded the previous draconic master. The spoils of this rivalry is an enormous accumulation of wealth, lore, and slaves, more than enough to convince the successor to ignore ghostly whispers, even as the growing number of restless ghosts attempt to drive them insane.

Whichever dragon controls the lair names themselves 'Sicnavier', a title that has passed to no fewer than six dragons over the centuries. Attempts by outsiders to slay the dragon usually fail, but on those rare occasions when an attempt succeeds, a new, younger dragon takes on the mantle for him or herself.

The deepest pits of Sicnavier's Lair connects to the Darklands, although the dragon master and the creatures below have limited interaction with one another.

As of 4711 AR the ruler was Sicnavier VI, a very old umbral dragon who is said to have been driven to near madness from the tormenting whispers of its slain kin. Other inhabitants, such as Dark folk, nightwings, and tenebrous worms, also inhabit the lair and are most frequently slaves or pets of their draconic overlord.

The Silken Court is a brothel in the Petal District of Absalom. It is the city's most expensive establishment of its type, and among of the Inner Sea's most famous. Previously owned and managed by Elissa the Fair until her recent retirement, it has since been fully renovated by its new manager, the Calistrian Head Hetaera Dyrianna of House Avenstar.

The jagged metallic peak of the Silver Mount is the above-ground remnant of the largest of the fallen starships that crashed in Numeria during the legendary Rain of Stars thousands of years ago. The edifice is honeycombed with chambers and was once heavily guarded by servants of the since-defunct Technic League.

This scarred monolith looms over the capital city of Starfall and the strange knowledge and technology found therein is the source of much of the Black Sovereign's (and Technic League's) power. Even though Silver Mount is closely guarded by the soldiers of the Black Sovereign, certain brave scholars and adventurers continue to try and enter the structure in the hopes of discovering untold wealth or technology from beyond this world.

The Silver Span, formerly known as Bleakbridge, is the sole bridge connecting the two halves of Kintargo across the Yolubilis River and links the districts of Yolubilis Harbor with Redroof. The Silver Span also serves as one of the city's greatest markets, as it is lined with wooden shops from end to end on both sides with smaller markets nestled round either end of the bridge.

The bridge is 475 feet long, consisting of stone arches that peak 10 feet above the water, and are supported by eight large stone towers that also serve the local Dottari as guardposts. All types of shops line the bridge, including food stores, a cobbler, a hatter, curio shops, and a florist.

The Silver Span is also home to unique gang of tengu toughs called The River Talons who act as cutpurses, thieves and general nuisances who never quite made the leap from street gang to thieves' guild.
The Silver Spindle, formerly known as The Devil's Threads, is one of the many tailor's shops located adjacent to the Redroof Market in the Redroof district of Kintargo.
The Silver Star, once a music store in the foreign quarter of the Jarvis End district of Kintargo, is as of 4724 AR a vacant lot.

Silver Suppers is a fish market, restaurant, and salmon-themed gift shop located in the Yolubilis Harbor district of Kintargo, Ravounel. As of 4724 AR its proprietor was salmon magnate and philanthropist Tevandis Sastrien.

Siren's Lash is a temple in Port Peril devoted to the goddess Calistria in her aspect as a deity of lust. As of 4712 AR, the courtesans of Siren's Lash were often invited to attend parties at the Hurricane King's palace of Lucrehold, but they also served as secret information brokers.

The temple's aiuvarin high priestess Mistress Livdana Giedrence is a known aficionado of all things Kyonin, and anyone able to procure Livdana a gift from the elven kingdom is practically guaranteed to earn an audience with her.

Siren's Lash was once devoted to the goddess of love Shelyn and contains many architectural features of the goddess, including topiary gardens and exotic bird gardens.

Skull Hill is a Chelaxian fort located in the southern reaches of the Hold of Belkzen in a region known as the Skittermounds.

The fortification marks the furthest extent of the Everwar campaign and the conquest of Cheliax. The fort was used for mercenary recruitment and weapons trading. Skull Hill consists of a motte and bailey keep, surrounded by a wooden wall with a surrounding moat.

Until recently, it was believed to have been destroyed not long after the events of the Everwar but, in fact, continued to be used as part of a spy network to monitor orc activities: an attempt by Cheliax to ensure the protection of its southern territories.

The fortress was invaded and sacked in 4709 AR by a tribe of orcs known as the Skittering Ravagers who had been terrorising the region for years.

Skull's Crossing is the name of the massive arched dam that holds back the waters of the Storval Deep, releasing a steady stream into the Skull River. Located in central Varisia it is an ancient ruin from the Thassilonian era over 10,000 years ago.

The Slave Trenches of Hakotep are a series of large earthworks in Osirion built by Pharaoh Hakotep I between the Barrier Wall mountains and the headwaters of the Crook River, near the Kho-Rarme Pass. The earthworks run in strange geometric shapes across 17 square miles of desert, only from above can their true form be appreciated as the trenches form an ancient Osirian Hieroglyph that roughly translates as "Let Earth call down and bind the Sky".

The trenches' depths vary from only a few feet to fifty feet at its deepest but averages around thirty feet, their width can also vary widely but on average is around fifty feet. The trenches are often filled with drifts of sand and the bones of the slaves who died in their thousands carving them. The walls of the trench are dotted with some thousands of obelisks in various states of erosion and disrepair, about half of which are still intact. Each once housed a bound elemental, normally earth or air but sometimes fire, and the trenches still buzz with this mystic energy.

The trenches also feature towering menhirs made of polished white stone that have weathered the millennia much better than some of the surrounding stonework. The eleven menhirs are each devoted to one of the Osirian pantheon deities: Osiris, Horus, Isis, Thoth, Khepri, Ptah, Maat, Sekhmet, Ra, Sobek, and Set. The trenches also house several underground complexes which few have ever survived to explore. According to an Osiriontologist known as the Sand Sage, a tower-sized panel of hieroglyphics composed of the purest amber, also known as the Amber Chronograph, is located deep within the Slave Trenches. These hieroglyphs are numbers which are slowly counting down.

The trenches are inhabited by a unique form of undead called ossumentals that are found nowhere else. The trenches' inhabitants include Kenjutret, an immortal roc that once served as the loyal pet of Hakotep I as well as a sphinx obsessed with the mystery of the trenches. The area surrounding the Slave Trenches of Hakotep is known to be home to a variety of undead and elementals, rift drakes, a tribe of ash giants far from their home in the Mana Wastes and even a phoenix.

The Sleeper is a gigantic monument located in the north-easternmost spur of the Mindspin Mountains within the Hold of Belkzen. It resembles an enormous dragon wrapped around a mountaintop. Steam or smoke seems to emanate from its massive maw, which is large enough to fit an entire house.

The sculpture contains a series of chambers coiled around the mountain peak that lead into its hollow interior. Beneath the Sleeper, deep in the heart of the mountain, is the ancient city of Xin-Gastash. The gigantic monument was the great entrance to the ancient capital of the Thassilonian realm of gluttony, Gastash.

Belkzen natives now call the sculpture the Sleeper. Only the bravest climb the mountain's slopes, much less enter the interior chambers. The local orcs, being naturally superstitious, stay away from the Sleeper and consider it a cursed ruin full of bad magic. The chambers within the Sleeper are mostly intact, although many of them show signs of earthquake damage.

The Sleeping Dove is a shrine dedicated to Sarenrae located in the western reaches of central Katapesh, less than 100 miles east of Solku.

The history of Sleeping Dove is not a happy one: over 100 years ago, a group of pilgrims dedicated to Sarenrae were on a pilgrimage to Solku when they were ambushed by monstrous bandits—some say kholo, while others say jackalweres—and were slaughtered. A week later the bodies were found by passing travellers, who saw their tattered white gowns blowing in the wind and thought they looked like doves.

Several paladins from Solku came out to the site and built a shrine to Sarenrae here to remember their fallen brethren. Ever since the shrine of Sleeping Dove has been sacred ground. Many a traveller stops to rest by the shrine as it seems to repel evil creatures and has even granted mysterious, and sometimes prophetic, dreams to good and devout creatures.

Once a reasonably prosperous village, Slither Cove is now nothing but a sinking ruin being rapidly consumed by the surrounding swamp. Slither Cove's current name comes from the wide variety of snakes, lizards, and other reptiles that now inhabit it.

The northernmost Narlmarches contain a snare-filled glade, trapped by a notorious trapper by the name of Breeg Orlivanch. While most trappers keep a close eye on their traps and feel a responsibility to warn others of their presence, Breeg finds cruel enjoyment in hiding his traps from animals and humans alike. Although the trapper is already dead, his specially crafted spike snares continue to litter the glade.

Sokar's Boil is one of Osirion's two volcanoes—the other is the nearby Asuulek's Mouth. Both are located in the country's southwestern region known as the Footprints of Rovagug. Sokar's Boil (or just the Boil as it is sometimes called) is currently dormant. The last eruption took place some three thousand years ago and was extremely violent.
The Solitary Pool is a small oasis and caravanserai in the Meraz Desert of Qadira. It is operated by Razinia, who appears to visitors disguised as a jann but is secretly a ghul.

The massive manor known as Sombrefell Hall is located about 25 miles northeast of Rozenport in Ustalav. It is situated at the end of a fairly well demarcated road abutting the Lantern Lake. The manor has belonged to the Oscilar family for generations. It is built in the gothic Ustalavic fashion and its grand entrance consists of mahogany double doors.
Songbird Hall is the temple to Shelyn in the city of Kintargo, Ravounel, and is both the city's third-largest temple and its most trafficked. Its high priest as of 4724 AR was Zachrin Vhast.

Soth-Silir is a 30-foot-tall, oddly shaped monument on the northern edge of the Ombrefell, guarded by the Xoskerik tribe of shadow giants led by their priest Salifeth. Several shelters serve as homes for the shadow giants, who patrol the Atteran Ranches, inspiring both respect and fear. The sacrifice of Nidalese heretics is common at the monument and their provision forms part of the Xoskerik's agreement with the Umbral Court. Not all heretics are suitable for sacrifice: some are eaten instead; those deemed unfit are exiled to Varisia through the Uthori Pass.

The Sphinx Head or Black Sphinx is the largest sphinx statue in Osirion, located in the desert between Shiman-Sekh and the Junira River. It is constructed from black granite, and has sunk up to its chin in the desert sands. Its features are believed to be those of the Sky Pharaoh, Menedes I, staring into the center of Osirion.

A 5-foot-wide and 25-foot-deep, densely webbed spider nest sits among the plant life of the Rostland Hinterlands, about a dozen miles southwest from Bokken's Hut. It is home to a spider as large as a pony, which hides the entrance of its lair with a trapdoor of hardened soil and waits for creatures to ambush. The nest's position is only given away by the skeletons of its prey, littering a 20-foot radius around the shaft hidden in their center. The scattered bones belong to deer, boars, bears, and humans.

The Spider's Nest is crater several miles in diameter located as of 4713 AR in Irrisen. It formed in 4529 AR when a gigantic explosion shook the eastern Hoarwood Forest, and out poured plumes of smoke, fire, and giant spiders. Queen Yelizaveta sent her armies to defeat this sudden spider horde before it could spread much beyond the forest, and they succeeded. Few have explored the area since, and no one yet knows the cause of the original explosion.

A Thassilonian relic from ancient times, the Spindlehorn is a fantastically tall structure located in the Wyvern Mountains of central Varisia. Thousands of feet in height, it rises from the shores of the Storval Deep, contradicting all natural laws of architecture and engineering. It is completely featureless except for a winding stair that winds like a corkscrew around its length, terminating in an open platform ten feet in diameter. The view from this platform is easily one of the most terrifying views in all of Golarion.

To most, the purpose of the spire has been lost to time, although it is told that dark-robed figures can be seen ascending, but never descending its heights from time to time. However, there is an epic poem Jandelay, inscribed at the base of the Spindlehorn, that implies that Jandelay is place of green fields and spires somewhere within the chaos of the Maelstrom, and that a being called the Oliphaunt of Jandelay is Jandelay's eternal guardian. So, some have surmised that Spindlehorn was constructed as a platform from which one could summon the Oliphaunt of Jandelay and command it while making eye contact with the massive creature.

Shamans of the Shoanti Shundar-Quah hold the Spindlehorn sacred, making pilgrimages there once every ten years to discuss tribal matters of import. Rumors suggest a powerful being is buried beneath the tower's base, and the site remains a powerful point for summoning monstrously large fiends.

The Spiral of Bones is a communal cemetery on the edge of the Fangwood where 333 Nirmathi rebels who died during the first assault on Tamran are buried. While the graves were being dug, a sinkhole opened up, swallowing the corpses. Because they were preoccupied with the war, the hole was never excavated, nor were the bodies recovered, and rumors of vengeful spirits keep people away from the site. The area inside the sinkhole overlooks a hryngar settlement that was abandoned when the local ore ran out, though recently a group of prospectors, led by a hryngar named Asdynn the Breaker, have been attempting to reclaim the citadel. Because many monsters from the Darklands have claimed parts of the citadel, clearing it will take a considerable amount of time.

The Spire of Destiny is a tall formation of white rock that rises 300 feet above the surface of Lake Ocota in the Mwangi Jungle. Its unusually regular appearance is the subject of a number of legends. The local Zenj tribes believe it may have been built by titans. A more mythical tale claims that it is the spear of Gozreh, which the deity thrust into the earth in order to bring forth the region's many rivers.

The Spire of Lemriss, also called the Green Spire of Lemriss, is a tree-like growth hundreds of feet in height located in western Varisia on the border between the Fogscar Mountains and the Churlwood. Its core is composed of braided and twisted wooden trunks, surrounded by arm-deep shell of vines. Countless birds and forest creatures make their home within its near-vertical structure, their chirps and hoots heard for miles around. Some believe that the spire is a cutting from the World Tree, although this has never been proven.

The Spire of Nex, also called the Tower of Nex, is a tall siege castle created by the archmage Nex as part of his unsuccessful siege of Absalom in 166 AR. Nex constructed it using a shard from his personal demiplane known as the Crux of Nex.

The Spiritscar is an enormous, trench-like rift located in the northern hills of Kaoling in Tian Xia. Over seven miles long and nearly 800 feet deep, Spiritscar was once the location of a monastery dedicated to Lady Nanbyo, the Widow of Suffering. Dating back to the days of Imperial Lung Wa, even before the formation of the rift, the area that would become the Spiritscar had long been associated with misery. When hobgoblin forces first attacked the monastery, the cultists of Lady Nanbyo triggered a massive earthquake that destroyed everyone and created the current rift. The Spiritscar is now haunted by the ghosts of both the cultists and the hobgoblin army that attacked them.

The ancient ruined fortress of Spiro Spero lies north of the Ndele Gap, on the Mwangi Expanse side of the Shattered Range. It takes its name from the spiral pathway that winds its way up the mountainside to its gate.
Spry's Heart is a dark and tangled part of the Embeth Forest in the River Kingdom of Uringen. The area seems to attract evil fey and corrupt good ones, and is the home of the grig Mather Nithra.

St. Caspieran's Salvation, also called St. Caspieran's Mission, is an almshouse and temple of Sarenrae founded decades prior to 4708 AR by St. Caspieran, an idealistic Sarenite priest and missionary who comforted the unfortunate, drunk, and orphaned.
St. Ilnea's Fountain is a spring in a rock-ringed vale along the Menador Mountains, just west of the Chelaxian town of Taggun Hold in the Archduchy of Menador.

Star Keep is a fortress on the Mendevian banks of the West Sellen River that overlooks the southeastern plains of Sarkoris. As of 4716 AR, prior to the Worldwound's closing, it was staffed by a number of holy paladin orders who worked independently from the national command in Nerosyan. Rumors along the Crusader Road claimed that the soldiers of the keep launched strikes deep into the Worldwound to track demonic troop movements, or made precise incursions to take down particularly troublesome opponents.

The fate of Star Keep since the closure of the Worldwound is unknown.

The Star Titan's Grave is the crash site of a city-sized object that fell in the eastern Valashmai Jungle and is where the fabled kaiju Agamazar the Star Titan first emerged onto Golarion.

In -44 AR (or 2456 IC), an ill-omened shooting star burned across the skies of Tian Xia, witnessed from one end of the continent to the other. This burning comet was unlike any ever seen, as it was clearly some kind of artificial construction the size of a city and in the shape of a man. This vexing event was carefully observed by the astrologers of Xa Hoi who were unable to chart its trajectory beyond determining that it fell somewhere in the Valashmai Jungle.

Since then, countless expeditions have set off into the jungle to find the Star Titan's Grave and over two dozen claim to have reached it. The most reputable of these explorers all met a gruesome end shortly after their return to civilisation from a wasting disease that stripped flesh from bone and did not respond to any kind of magical treatment.

The Starrise Spire, the tallest building in Nerosyan, is located on the city's outer wall in the Confluence District neighborhood of Coopertown. It is topped by a celestial light that continuously shines in even the darkest of nights and never fades as long as at least one defender still resides in the tower. This beacon provided hope and relief to adventurers that crusaders still stood against the demons of the Worldwound, and continues to operate as a center of restoration efforts since the Worldwound's closure into the Sarkoris. Before the Pathfinder Society was tasked to protect the city, the city's crusaders defended its walls.

The Starrise Spire's venture-captain is Jorsal of Lauterbury, a well-decorated Mwangi man with over 50 advances into the Worldwound under his belt. Jorsal delegates divine magic training and consecration of the Spire's holy sites to Seeker Ereth Brightmane.

Arguably the most sacred location in all of Golarion, the Starstone Cathedral is a monument to divinity. The massive structure was created by Aroden when he raised the Starstone from the depths of the Inner Sea in 1 AR, and the relic is believed to rest within to this day.

The Stasis Fields are a mysterious prison in the Bandu Hills. They consist of numerous underground caverns; in each cavern a solitary figure is held in stasis, floating in mid-air and turning slowly in time with the world's rotation.

Each prisoner wears turquoise scale armour and is armed with shining blades, giving rise to speculation that they are all prisoners of war from a long-forgotten army. Brave (or foolhardy) adventurers sometimes try to steal their equipment; no one knows what would happen if this caused a prisoner to awaken.

It was discovered in 4516 AR.

The Stavian Ranches are home to the finest horses in all of Taldor, for they are the horses ridden by the royal lineage. Founded by Stavian I, the stables breed Taldan horses used by the cavalry, although breeding Qadiran horses is forbidden by royal decree. Stavian III's horse, Dycephalus, traces his lineage back to the horse ridden by his great-grandfather, Kaillerophon.
The Steam Pit is a massive sinkhole located in the Linnorm Kingdom of Icemark. Nearly 500 feet in diameter, the pit emits foul-smelling steam and hot air, and is believed by the Varki to be cursed.

The Steirwood is a small rotting forest on the Raugsmauda's Reach island in the Shackles. The forest was once home to many animals but now hosts the majority of the hordes of undead that aimlessly roam the island. Raugsmauda creates her necromantic horrors using victims she captures on her monthly hunts. Some of the terrible creatures that wander Steirwood resemble animals that perhaps once populated the isle or distant lands, including bovine ghasts, elephantine skeletons, and serpentine ghouls. The winding tainted trees spontaneously animate their barbed roots to gore and consume zombie animals that wander too close.
The Stepped Tower of Djedefar is a site in northern Osirion. It is located on the north eastern tip of the Alamein Peninsula. The tower is home to a community of Irori-worshiping monks.

The Steps of the Agate King is a massive pyramid located within the depths of the Sparadyn Jungle in central Katapesh. The pyramid lists gently to the west having sunk into the earth. The pyramid is made of large blocks streaked with red and golden agate that make it dazzling to look upon.

It is generally accepted by all the citizens of Katapesh, despite a lack of scholarly evidence, that the Steps of the Agate King bar the way to the underground tomb of the legendary Agate King. People also accept that he took all the trappings of life with him when he was buried, and that somewhere buried beneath is a king's fortune.

While there is an underground section to the site, it lies completely empty, perhaps stripped bare of its former wealth, or perhaps never having any in the first place. Regardless, every year a few hardy souls visit the Steps of the Agate King desperately looking for the rumoured treasure-filled tomb layer.

The mythical Stone of Tears was once a singular structure within a Ghol-Gani city that is now in ruins on the Dahak's Tooth island of the Shackles. The Stone of Tears lies sideways, having fallen from its ornate pedestal near the city's temple. It is said that the Stone of Tears was a cage for a beautiful nymph who long opposed the empire of Ghol-Gan and was imprisoned. Should she be released, her knowledge could reveal valuable secrets of the lost civilization.
Magnimar's most respectable school of arcane instruction, the Stone of the Seers, stands next to the Seerspring Gardens and its legendary spring.

Storasta was once one of the greatest cities of the Kellid nation of Sarkoris in northeastern Avistan. Founded in 3844 AR, it was finally abandoned in 4644 AR like the rest of the Worldwound. During its occupation, Storasta was overrun by demons until it was freed at the end of the Fifth Mendevian Crusade. Due to its complete corruption, however, the crusaders decided to raze the city rather than rebuild it.

Stormhollow, formerly known as Lorra's Hollow, was a village located in the Umbral Basin that was destroyed by velstracs during a shadowstorm. The village was founded by halflings who escaped the empire of Cheliax and sought a more fulfilling life. Those hopes were shattered by the velstrac attack, which transformed the inhabitants into greater shadows that now roam the village. Their houses are now filled with spikes and nails, and the flora has vanished from the streets.

The Stormspear Keep of the Blackravens is located at the northeastern corner of the region of Hagreach in the Lands of the Linnorm Kings. It is a complex of towers perched upon a cliff nearly 2,000 feet high at the northernmost edge of the border between Hagreach and Irrisen. The Blackraven warriors are allied with many nests of giant eagles, who help them patrol the northern borders.

Built thousands of years ago by the enslaved giants of the Thassilonian empire, the Storval Stairs are a set of stair-like tiers carved into the side of the western Storval Rise, then part of Shalast. Although sized for a gigantic creature, they are by far the easiest way to cross the Rise west of the Iron Peaks. It is not uncommon for the Storval Rise to reach heights of over 1,000 feet in many places, sharply delineating the fertile lowlands from the barren scrub land of the Storval Plateau. At the Storval Stairs, however, the Rise is only 400 feet in height with human-sized steps and ramps cut into the gargantuan ones, making the passage even easier. Immense statues of the runelord Karzoug flank the stairs, although the southern-most one is beginning to finally crumble due to erosion.
Sueda Lodge is a Pathfinder lodge in southeastern Katapesh that aids Pathfinders and other explorers searching for ancient Osirian artifacts, and also serves as a repository for information.

Close to Vargas Swamp, where the desert gives away to the swamp, underground water channels turn the ground to mud in a patch known as Suketh'ma. A large patch of sand conceals countless quicksand pits interspersed with muddy ditches, and travelers frequently disappear forever in the sucking pits. The mire is home to many sand eels.
The Sulfur Gulch is a large module of an ancient spaceship that once stored toxic gases used for various ship functions. As of 4716 AR it was slowly leaking the gases it contains, giving it its name.
Sumitha is an ancient Ghol-Gani ruin on the Island of Empty Eyes in the Shackles.

Summer Grove, in Nidal's southern Uskwood, is reachable solely in midsummer and absent the rest of the year. This hidden glade exudes beauty and tranquility. Wildflowers and lush grasses thrive beneath fragrant linden and sweet cherry trees. The albino Shades of the Uskwood druids and their spiders have never disrupted this place.
Summerglen is a deep-sided canyon in the Linnorm Kingdom of Hagreach whose walls are studded with crystals that seem to capture the warmth of the sun, increasing the canyon's temperature.

Summershade Granite Quarry is about seventy miles up the Katharevousa River from the Revousa Ditches. Once a significant source of granite for buildings in Whiterock and Kintargo, it was abandoned as uneconomical by House Jhaltero shortly before Ravounel's secession.
Sun Dagger is a ruined solar observatory in the eastern Fierani Forest of Kyonin that was abandoned by the elves when they abandoned Golarion just before Earthfall.
The Sunbleached Tower is a bizarre location north of the Qadiran city of Dimayen. It is a massive edifice over 300 feet tall made of interlocking human bones that seems to attract daemons.

Sunhill Monastery is located on a plateau just west of the Zho Mountains of Qadira. The complex contains chapels to both the empyreal lord Ragathiel and the goddess Sarenrae. It is the headquarters of the Eleli who are overseen by a peri named Nuryah.

Sunken City is a Thassilonian ruin under the waves in the Howling Straits in the northern reaches of Broken Bay. Known as Udeomel to historians, the sunken city would have been a northerly settlement of Cyrusian.

The Sunken Queen, once known as the Shining Queen, is a partially submerged Thassilonian pyramid built over 10,000 years ago by the Runelord Sorshen in what was then the nation of Eurythnia. It is located in southern Varisia in an enormous swampland known as the Mushfens, approximately 160 miles west of the city of Korvosa.

After Earthfall, the Nidalese people faced crop challenges due to the lack of sunlight. Zon-Kuthon provided a solution: the Sunless Pond in the Uskwood. This supernatural spring feeds a pond whose dark water has plant growth-enhancing properties. Shades of the Uskwood druids distribute its water annually to peasants, collecting taxes for the water while assessing the arcane potential of local children. Despite the weak sun's return, farmers still rely on the pond's water to bolster crops for survival, attending gatherings for the precious resource despite the unpleasantness involved.

Sunset Imports is a harborfront import house in Kintargo that was among the city's wealthiest companies until losing its contracts with House Thrune in 4715 AR. Its fortunes have improved as of 4724 AR due to its role in fostering trade with the distant continent of Arcadia.

The Sunstone Cliffs lie in the very north-eastern corner of the Thanelands in the Lands of the Linnorm Kings in the foothills of the Stormspear Mountains range. The cliffs are famous for the gemstones found there called Thrain sunstones, unique gems that glow with a warm yellow light and whose flaws allow knowledgeable users to determine which way is north. Named for the prospector who discovered them, Thrain sunstones vary from smaller, inferior gems with the brightness of a candle to those that glow like a lantern and any jewellery made from sunstones will fetch huge prices across the Inner Sea region.

Unfortunately, the Sunstone Cliffs are a very dangerous region since they serve as the hunting ground for large groups of trolls and even rock trolls making it particularly dangerous at night. Those who come here to prospect for Thrain sunstones have to harvest them with great stealth and in very quick runs lest they end up as troll food.

The Sureshire Ranch is a horse ranch located in the Ligos Prefecture of Taldor with a storied history and national fame. According to Sureshire family, the first horse was bred here as a cross between a deer and a unicorn. Fanciful tales aside, the Sureshire Ranch has a millennia-long pedigree of horse breeding, and both the nation's aristocracy and Taldor's military favour its horses. Unlike the hulking brutes of the nearby Stavian Ranches, the horses of Sureshire are agile and quick, more akin to the horses favoured in the neighbouring kingdom of Qadira (whom the Sureshire family claims stole these horse from them).

The last of the Sureshire family died over six centuries ago. As of 4717 AR, the ranch is run by a council of Taldan and halfling families who proudly sponsor the Emperor's Mile, a gruelling horse race across the Ligos Prefecture that the ranch has sponsored for 1,200 years. Its winner is not only showered in gold but gains access to Well of Kurgess, a spring whose water enhances any beast of burden that drinks from it.

Situated in the Narlmarch Woods, the Swamp Village is a generous name for what amounts to nothing more than two dilapidated stone buildings on the eastern bank of the Skunk River. Nonetheless, these long-abandoned structures have recently been claimed by a boggard named Garuum and his pet slurk Ubagub.
The Swamp of the Dark Brood is a very dangerous place. Boiling pools of acid and dangerous predators are common here. Many iruxi tribes call this place home, and are often warring with each other.

Swan's Shadow Theater is a venue in the Old Kintargo neighborhood of Kintargo, Ravounel, that fell into ruin during the city's brief rule under Barzillai Thrune in 4715–4716 AR, during which it was confiscated and used by the church of Asmodeus. Following the Kintargan Rebellion its ownership was assumed by the city of Kintargo, and as of 4724 AR it had been abandoned since.

As of 4715 AR, Sweet Tooth was a small confectionery shop located in the Old Kintargo district of Kintargo, sharing a roof with the adjacent Tooth and Nail tavern. It is renowned for its candied blackberry tarts, which the owner, Luculla Gens, often sells in the neighbouring Tooth and Nail. Gens and Setrona Sabinus, proprietor of the Tooth and Nail, were once friends.

Gens was secretly a changeling and led Kintargo's secret cult dedicated to Mahathallah, the Dowager of Illusions. Her criminal activity was revealed after the Ruby Massacre of 4716 AR, and the shop's fate after the Kintargan Rebellion of 4715–4716 AR is unknown.
Swift Dolphin Warehouse is a failed, boarded-up warehouse in Magnimar's Underbridge district. Unknown to most is that under this site, the Midnight Dawn operate a drug parlor serving midnight milk.

Szigo's Grove is the home of Szigo, the cannibal warlock of the Grungir Forest, who eats his victims in order to gain power. Many adventurers have attempted to destroy this deranged madman, but Szigo has a sizeable following of violent trolls and other monstrous creatures that Szigo has convinced that he is a god.

Szigo's minions serve him as both hunter-gatherers and guards for the horde of magical treasure he has amassed over the years. The most famous item in this horde is probably the magical sword of Laughing Erik, the hero who supposedly came closest to vanquishing the terrible cannibal.

Approximately six centuries ago, dwarves constructed the ossuary of Taal Mornat especially for the servants of the Cathedral of Magrim in Larrad as well as other faithful servants of the dwarven god. The necropolis lies some twenty miles west of the city in a hidden valley within the peaks of the Five Kings Mountains. Over time, due to the fame of many laid to rest there, the site is now a holy and cultural centre for the dwarven community.
Tafinyah is a small, little-known stronghold in Qadira's Tapur Forest that is home to the Hatharat, the nation's intelligence agency and diplomatic corps.

Talamir, now known as Dragonscar, was a wealthy city whose prideful citizens once painted many of its buildings green and blue to match the flag of Taldor. It is now an ash-encrusted ruin charred by both volcanic and draconic flame.
Tanessen Estate, located in the Greens district of Kintargo, Ravounel, is the home of House Tanessen.

Tanglegate is an elf gate in the demon-corrupted forest of Tanglebriar. It can be reached via Lichgate, which is the only known example of a working elf gate that links to Tanglebriar. Its portal key is a sapphire.

Treerazer, the lord of Tanglebriar, hopes one day to be able to use Tanglegate against the elves, and so he has ordered his minions to refrain from destroying it. The gate itself is a stone arch covered in moss, and it stands on a rare patch of dry ground in the middle of a stinking bog.
Taranik House is a large mansion in the Rego Scripa section of the Chelaxian city of Westcrown, which serves as the city's garrison for the Hellknight Order of the Rack.
The Tarry Imp is a coffee house and restaurant in the Jarvis End district of Kintargo, capital of Ravounel. Its service is geared to actors and writers.

The ruins of Tashagrot are all that remains of the capital of the former Irriseni province of Rimetusk, wiped out by predators coming from the Realm of the Mammoth Lords that were eager to regain their old territories. It is said that the site, which lies on the eastern bank of the Gullik River south of Coldwater, is haunted by its massacred residents.
Tazion is an ancient Azlanti ruin located in the southern Mwangi Jungle of the Mwangi Expanse.

Te Taspeh Valley is a peaceful land dotted with the ruins of ancient wooden homes believed to be the surviving remnants of Mendev's once-nomadic society. Unusual carvings associate these buildings with these ancient people, who were believed to settle only in locations of great spiritual importance.

As of 4725 AR the valley's ruins had yet to be investigated in large part due to the possessive behavior of a nearby adamantine dragon.

The Telus Estate stands just outside the ruined town of Jambis in Meratt County. For a minor noble's manor house, the Telus Estate actually boasts an incredibly long history, having served as a border fortress since the earliest days of Taldor's founding. The estate is made of solid, ancient stone that has been covered in more refined white plaster. The estate sits on a hill above Jambis but has been severely neglected for over a decade, ever since Baron Araig Telus was cursed by a coven of night hags and transformed into a flesh-hungry ettercap.

Temple Canyon is a mysterious site on the southern Tandak Plains, north of the settlement of Old Sehir. This long, dry canyon is over 30 miles in length and at times reaches several hundred feet deep. In the earliest days of Taldor, Temple Canyon served as a burial site for the nation's emperors, aristocrats, and heroes of legend. The buried wealth of Temple Canyon was almost entirely picked clean thousands of years ago but the now empty tombs still serve as a repository of Taldor's ancient history.

Nowadays, the tombs of Temple Canyon are picked over by looters looking to carve away some of the ancient carvings and statuary in the vague hope of selling it on to Taldor's modern nobility. Lucky finds do still occur and in 4556 AR the tomb of Princess Modavora was discovered still intact, making the survivors of the expedition fantastically wealthy. Temple Canyon is considered a sacred site by House Stavian and the rangers who patrol its length happily execute any unauthorised intruders they catch within the canyon.
The Temple of An-Alak is a site in desert of eastern Osirion. It is located between the Underdunes and the Salt Hills.

The Temple of Gogunta on Lady's Cape in southwestern Varisia, near the site of the Lady's Light, is a cavern considered to be a sacred place of the deity Gogunta by local boggards. As of 4712 AR, an informal village of boggards existed near the marshy pond about 200 yards east of the cavern. The cavern is one of several that connect to tunnels which run beneath the Lady's Lagoon.

Sometimes called the Church of Iomedae, the Magnimarian Temple of Iomedae is one of the largest temples in the 'City of Monuments'. The fortress-like building is dedicated to Iomedae, the goddess of justice and honour, and run by Chaplain Tira Ronnova. The temple is located in the Naos district of the city.

The waterlogged Temple of Xanthuun is located off the coast of the Eribastos Peninsula in the eastern Sodden Lands. It contains the legendary treasure hoard of Ammelon VI, last ruler of the pre-historic cyclops kingdom of Ghol-Gan.

The Temple of the Elk is an overgrown and forgotten shrine to Erastil in the northern Narlmarches. A dense growth of brambles and other thorny plants envelops the expansive clearing where it is situated, deep within the forest.

The Temple of the Eternal Obelisk is an ancient, buried temple found below the salt flats of the northern Ketz Desert of Qadira. One of the Pathfinder Chronicles holds rumors that the Eternal Obelisk within contains the secret of eternal youth.

The Temple of the Ravenous Moon, originally just called the Temple of the Moon, is in the Terwa Uplands, in an area considered to lie within the Shackles. It is an ancient ziggurat constructed of a red-veined white stone.

It gets its name from the carvings on its walls, which show scenes of mass sacrifices under a grinning, befanged moon. The savage kuru tribes which live in the region avoid the temple.

The Hurricane King, leader of the Shackles Pirates, has sent two missions to investigate the temple, but neither of them returned. It is rumoured that the Pathfinder Society may be preparing to send its own expedition from Nantambu; plus Hemdak Wavebaiter has called for adventurers to explore the temple in an attempt to garner himself favour with the Hurricane King.
The Temple of the Sunken Sign is a Ghol-Gani temple complex dedicated to Azathoth, hidden in the Sodden Lands.

The Temple of the Whispering Spider is a ruined temple of Lao Shu Po, located in Eryiu Forest of northwestern Quain, that is now inhabited by an enormous arachnid said to be the spirit of a cursed ancient priestess or royal maiden who rejected being sacrificed to have her heart become a celestial pearl. Villages near the temple revere her as living testament of righteous defiance in the face of evil. They also say the arachnid is the only thing holding back the spirits believed to live within the temple and leave regular offerings of silver, forage, and meat at its entrance.

The Temples of Pharaoh Ahn is a site in southeastern Osirion located between the Salt Hills and the Brazen Peaks from the brief reign of Pharaoh Ahn, who ruled after the Naga Pharaoh. Pharaoh Ahn believed himself to be as powerful as the mortal Nethys, to such a point that he was nearly driven insane. He ordered slaves and followers to this site in the Brazen Peaks in search of what his advisors told him might be the means used by Nethys to ascend to godhood.

While Pharaoh Ahn searched, his followers constructed inverted pyramids out of precious gemstones to serve as the first palace of what they believed would be their deity Ahn, and magically warded the structures from mortal incursions. Neither Pharaoh Ahn nor his followers returned, however, and later expeditions to the site found only bloody trails toward the pyramids.

As of 4714 AR, the site's only active researcher is Ali Ahmendi, who remained based in Sothis and claimed to be a descendant of Pharaoh Ahn's chief advisor. He employs adventurers in his attempts to explore the temples.

In the time of Imperial Lung Wa, the Ten Thousand Summer Palace in southern Bachuan, on the northern eaves of the Chang Liao Jungle, was a favorite winter retreat for many emperors. The palace was an enormous walled compound tended by a vast staff of sorcerers and clerics. During the Bachuan Revolution, the palace was besieged by the revolutionary armies, but its spellcasting inhabitants shut its gates and blasted the rebellious peasants to ash. The palace's gates never opened again.

Although the revolution succeeded in taking over Bachuan, no infiltrators have entered the Ten Thousand Summer Palace and returned to tell the tale, with one single exception. A mercenary from Minkai emerged, covered in glowing sigils and clutching a gigantic emerald, only to die as he stumbled into a nearby village muttering the words, "...beautiuful...terrible..."

The Tents of Erukh is an encampment of impossibly beautiful people located within the Alavah Peninsula of Qadira. The camp is built around a massive tent owned by the exiled jaathoom wizard Erukh, for whom the camp is named. Erukh refuses to explain why he was banished from the Elemental Plane of Air to the Universe. He accepts no gifts from those looking to curry his favour and instead asks the supplicant to perform a task for him. The few who manage to achieve their assigned tasks are invited deeper into the Tents of Erukh, where supposedly even more wonders abound.

Terapasillion (which means "Ziggurat of Night" in the Shadowtongue) is an ancient step pyramid eternally cloaked in shadows that predates Taldan settlement in the region, and is located on the southern North Plains of Ravounel near Nidal. It is rumored to have been built by shadow giants during the Age of Darkness, but was more recently inhabited by an umbral dragon. Despite the fact that the dragon has not been seen in decades, locals still avoid the place with a passion.

Tern Hill is a cavern in the Verduran Forest that collapsed, creating an open, roofless space. Tall trees surround the hill, their canopies blocking the view, while their thick roots are visible inside the cavern. Several tunnels connect the cavern's chambers, making it an easily defensible location.

The Rootweft Lodge used the cavern as a base of operations during the Wildwood Revolt, taking advantage of its defensive strengths.
